results.title: This way up (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Real thing”.
James Burke goes to the top of the Blackpool Tower and turns upside down to discover how the ears talk to the eyes and how we know which way is down.

results.title: The Private eye (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Mick Jackson and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Real thing”.
Shot in the style of a 1940’s film, James Burke employs a detective to illustrate how the senses pick up clues from the outside world, how the brain solves the mystery and decides what is out there. Illustrates how easy it is to fool the best detective, and asks “what is reality”? Part one of a series of six programs written and presented by James Burke. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Life sentence (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Mick Jackson and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Real thing”.
Part 6 of a series examining the latest research into the workings of the human brain. This film considers language and human use of it, noting how the meaning of a word can be changed by altering the pitch of the spoken word; how incorrect sentences can be corrected by the listener or the receiver of the information; how the use of grammar can change the information; how the use of grammar can change the meaning of words; and how many different concepts and associations can surround the use of one word, eg cat or girl. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Pressing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Preserving and Drying of Plant Material”.
One of three films dealing with different aspects of preserving and drying of plant material, showing the techniques and everyday domestic equipment needed to achieve satisfactory results. This film deals with preservation by pressing.

results.title: Furnace control
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Open hearth furnace series”.
Shows how temperature, pressure, gas and air flow are recorded and regulated by instruments to assist the melter in controlling the furnace.

results.title: Making open hearth steel
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare, British Iron and Steel Federation and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Open hearth furnace series”.
Chemical reactions by which steel is refined from iron and steel scrap are explained by animated sequences. The function of slag and the differences between acid and basic furnaces are also outlined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare, British Iron and Steel Federation and Merton Park

results.title: How it works
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Open hearth furnace series”.
An explanation of how the furnace is constructed to withstand the very high temperatures needed to make steel. The system of regeneration by which gas and air are heated before being burned in the furnace is also illustrated.
